revision.text:
'''Rapid phase transition''' or '''RPT''' is a phenomenon realized in [[liquefied natural gas]] (LNG) incidents in which LNG vaporizes violently upon coming in contact with [[water]] causing what is known as a ''physical explosion''<ref>[http://www.iomosaic.com/docs/training/Understand_LNG_RPT.pdf Understand LNG Rapid Phase Transitions (RPT)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130828015033/http://www.iomosaic.com/docs/training/Understand_LNG_RPT.pdf |date=2013-08-28 }}</ref> or ''cold explosion''.<ref>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/15490436/Lng-Hazard-AP Lng Hazard AP]</ref> During such explosions there is no combustion but rather a huge amount of [[energy]] is transferred in the form of heat from the room-temperature water to the LNG at a [[temperature]] difference of about 175 kelvins.
==LNG Properties== {{Main|Liquefied natural gas}} [[Liquefied natural gas]] or LNG is a natural gas that gets liquefied at atmospheric pressure and −161.5 °C. It is [[odorless]], [[tasteless]], colorless, and not [[poisonous]] but causes [[asphyxia]]. It can cause [[frostbite]] due to its [[cryogenic]] temperature. If this extremely cold LNG is mixed with water(e.g. [[sea water]], which has an average temperature of 15 °C), heat energy is transferred from the water to the LNG, rapidly [[Vaporization|vaporizing]] it from its liquefied state back into its original gaseous state. This results in an explosion because the volume occupied by natural gas in its gaseous form is 600 times greater than when its liquefied. This is the phenomenon of rapid phase transition.
==See also== * [[Dry ice bomb]] * [[BLEVE]] * [[Explosive boiling or phase explosion]]
==External links== * [http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=15602139 Latest developments in rapid-phase-transition modeling] * [http://www.energy.ca.gov/lng/glossary.html Glossary of LNG-Related Terms & Definitions]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Phase transitions]] [[Category:Explosions]] [[Category:Liquefied natural gas]]
{{energy-stub}}

[[File:Volodymyrskyi Descent.jpg|thumb|300px|Saint Volodymyr Descent, on a far side could be seen a building "Palestinian Filter" (1887)]] '''Saint Volodymyr Descent''' ({{lang-uk|Володимирський узвіз}}, Volodymyrsky uzviz) is a street in [[Kiev]] located between the [[Pechersk Raion|Pechersk]] and [[Podil Raion|Podil]] city districts. It stretches from [[European Square (Kiev)|European Square]] to [[Postal Square (Kiev)|Postal Square]].
The city street splits two city parks ([[Khreshchaty Park]] and [[Saint Volodymyr Hill]]) located on the slopes of Saint Michael Hill (see [[Kiev Mountains]]).
The street started to form in 1711 in place of the so-called ''Old Pechersk Road'' that used to connect Pechersk with Podil. As a city street it was known originally as ''Khreshchaty Drive'' ({{lang-uk|Хрещатицький приїзд}}, Khreshchatytsky pryizd) and later as ''Paved Street'' ({{lang-uk|Мостова вулиця}}, Mostova vulytsia) becoming the first city's street paved with [[cobblestone]]. Sometime in 1810s it became part of a long ''Aleksandr Street'' (after [[Alexander II of Russia]]) that stretched all the way from Arsenal Square to Contracts Square, while the descent was unofficially referred to as Aleksandr Descent. After the occupation of Kiev by the Soviet troops in March of 1919 the long street was renamed as Revolution Street ([[October Revolution]]). When Kiev became the capital of the [[Soviet Ukraine]] in 1934, the street was renamed once again, now as Sergei Kirov Street after the Russian government official [[Sergei Kirov]]. During the Nazi occupation the street along with the modern Hrushevsky Street carried the name of the Nazi political figure [[Fritz Todt]].
During the [[World War II]] when Kiev was freed from Nazi occupation, the former long Kirov Street was split at the Stalin Square (today [[European Square (Kiev)|European Square]]) into Kirov Street (today [[Hrushevsky Street (Kiev)|Hrushevsky Street]]) and Volodymyr Descent that stretched from the Stalin Square to [[Contracts Square (Kiev)|Contracts Square]]. In 1955 the street was shortened and part of it between Postal Square and Contracts Square was renamed into Zhdanov Street (today Sahaidachny Street) after a Soviet official [[Andrei Zhdanov]].
==External links== * [http://wek.kiev.ua/uk/%d0%92%d0%be%d0%bb%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b8%d0%bc%d0%b8%d1%80%d1%81%d1%8c%d0%ba%d0%b8%d0%b9_%d1%83%d0%b7%d0%b2%d1%96%d0%b7 Saint Volodymyr Descent] at the Kiev e-Encyclopedia
{{coord|50.4529|N|30.5279|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}
[[Category:Streets in Kiev]] [[Category:Cobbled streets]]

{{Infobox aircraft occurrence | name = Transportes Aéreos Portugueses Flight 425 | occurrence_type = Accident | image = TAP Portugal B-727 CS-TBS.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = A TAP Portugal Boeing 727-200, similar to the aircraft involved in the accident. | date = November 19, 1977| | type = Runway [[overshoot (aviation)|overshoot]] caused by [[pilot error]] | site = [[Cristiano Ronaldo International Airport|Madeira International Airport]], [[Funchal]], [[Portugal]] | coordinates = {{coord|32|41|17|N|16|47|8|W|type:event|display=inline,title}} | aircraft_type = [[Boeing 727|Boeing 727-282 Advanced]] | aircraft_name = ''[[Artur de Sacadura Cabral|Sacadura Cabral]]'' | operator = [[TAP Portugal|Transportes Aéreos Portugueses]] | tail_number = {{airreg|CS|TBR}} | passengers = 156 | crew = 8 | fatalities = 131 | injuries = | missing = | survivors = 33 | origin = [[Brussels Airport]], [[Belgium]] | stopover = | stopover0 = | last_stopover = [[Lisbon Portela Airport]], [[Portugal]] | destination = [[Cristiano Ronaldo International Airport|Madeira International Airport]], [[Funchal]], [[Portugal]] }} '''TAP Flight 425''' was a regular flight from [[Brussels]], Belgium, to [[Santa Catarina Airport]] (informally known as Funchal Airport or Madeira Airport; now the [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] International Airport), Portugal, with an intermediate scheduled stop in [[Lisbon]]. On November 19, 1977, the [[Boeing 727]] operating the service overran the airport's runway before crashing onto the nearby beach and exploding, killing 131 of the 164 people on board. It remains [[TAP Portugal|TAP]]'s only fatal accident in its history.
== Aircraft == {{unreferenced|section|date=November 2017}} The aircraft operating flight TP-425 was a [[Boeing 727|Boeing 727-282 Advanced]] registration CS-TBR named after the Portuguese aviation pioneer [[Sacadura Cabral]]. Its manufacturer serial number was 20972/1096 and it was delivered to TAP on 21 January 1975. It was powered by 3 [[Pratt & Whitney JT8D|Pratt & Whitney JT8D-17]] turbofan engines which had a maximum thrust of 16,000 lbf each. The aircraft had completed a B check on 21 September 1977, and at the time of the accident had accumulated 6,154 flying hours in 5,204 cycles.
== Accident == Shortly before 9:48pm on that Saturday evening, after 13 hours and 15 minutes of service time, the tired crew of the 727 was trying to land the airplane on the difficult Santa Catarina International Airport's runway, which at the time was {{convert|1600|m|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} long. After two unsuccessful attempts to land the aircraft, the [[Captain (civil aviation)|Captain]] João Lontrão and [[Co-pilot]] Miguel Guimarães Leal decided to make one last try to land the plane, before they would have to make the decision to divert to the [[Gran Canaria Airport]] in the [[Canary Islands]].{{CN|date=November 2016}}
While on final approach to runway 24 in heavy rain, strong winds and poor visibility, the aircraft touched down {{convert|2000|ft|sigfig=2}} past the threshold, and started hydroplaning. With just about {{convert|3000|ft|sigfig=2}} of runway left, the crew tried desperately to stop, applying maximum reverse thrust and brakes, but the aircraft slid off the runway with a ground speed of approximately {{convert|43|kn|km/h}} and plunged over a {{convert|200|ft|adj=on}} steep bank hitting a nearby bridge and crashing on the beach; splitting in two pieces and bursting into flames.<ref name=rtp>[[Rádio e Televisão de Portugal]] Documentary "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DLROUDrMquU TP425 - O voo interminável]" (aired November 14th 2007, in Portuguese)]</ref>
Of the 164 people aboard (156 passengers and eight crew), 131 were killed (125 passengers and 6 crew),<ref name=airdisater>[http://www.airdisaster.com/cgi-bin/view_details.cgi?date=11191977%C2%AE=CS-TBR&airline=TAP+Portugal AirDisaster.com Accident Database] listing for flight 425. Accessed 05/07/2008</ref> making it the deadliest airplane accident in Portugal to that point. As of 2018, it is the second deadliest airplane accident in Portugal, after [[Independent Air Flight 1851]]. It remains TAP Portugal's only fatal accident since the beginning of its flight operations in 1946.<ref name=onlyfatalaccident>[http://www.airsafe.com/events/airlines/tap.htm AirSafe.com - TAP Air Portugal plane crashes]</ref>
==Aftermath== After the accident occurred, TAP stopped flying the Boeing 727-200 to Madeira, and started flying only the 727-100, which was six metres shorter and took 60 fewer passengers.<ref name=rtp/>
The crash prompted officials to explore ways of extending the short runway. Because of the height of the runway relative to the beach below, an extension was very difficult and very expensive to perform.<ref name=rtp/> Between 1983 and 1986,<ref name=aeromadeira82>[http://www.aeroportosdamadeira.pt/1983-a-1986-42.aspx 1983-86 History of Madeira], the airport where flight 425 crashed. Accessed 20/02/2010 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091218023306/http://www.aeroportosdamadeira.pt/1983-a-1986-42.aspx |date=December 18, 2009 }}</ref> a 200 meter extension was built; 14 years later,<ref name=aeromadeira00>[http://www.aeroportosdamadeira.pt/2000-43.aspx 2000 History of Madeira], the airport where flight 425 crashed. Accessed 05/07/2008 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091218023651/http://www.aeroportosdamadeira.pt/2000-43.aspx |date=December 18, 2009 }}</ref> the runway was again extended. Following the 2000 extension, the runway of what is now the Cristiano Ronaldo International Airport measures {{convert|2781|m|abbr=on}} long and is capable of handling wide-body commercial jets like the [[Boeing 747]] or the [[Airbus A340]].

'''Thiocarbonate''' describes a family of [[anion]]s with the general [[chemical formula]] {{chem|CS|3−''x''|O|''x''|2−}} (''x'' = 0, 1, or 2). Organic compounds structurally related to these anions are also called thiocarbonates. Like the [[carbonate]] dianion, the thiocarbonates are [[plane (geometry)|planar]], with carbon at the center. The average [[bond order]] from C to S or O is {{frac|1|1|3}}. The state of protonation is usually not specified. These anions are good [[nucleophile]]s and good [[ligand]]s.Holleman, A. F.; Wiberg, E. "Inorganic Chemistry" Academic Press: San Diego, 2001. {{ISBN|0-12-352651-5}}. ==Monothiocarbonate== Monothiocarbonate is the dianion CO2S2−, which has C2v [[symmetry group|symmetry]]. Monothiocarbonate arises by the [[hydrolysis]] of [[thiophosgene]] or the reaction of base with [[carbonyl sulfide]]: :COS + 2 NaOH → Na2CO2S + H2O ==Dithiocarbonates== Dithiocarbonate is the dianion {{chem|COS|2|2−}}, which has C2v symmetry. It arises from the reaction of aqueous base with [[carbon disulfide]]: :CS2 + 2 NaOH → Na2COS2 + H2O Important derivatives dithiocarbonates are the [[xanthate]]s, with the formula {{chem|ROCS|2|−}}. These salts are typically prepared by the reaction of sodiium [[alkoxide]]s with carbon disulfide. Another group of dithiocarbonates have the formula (RS)2CO.{{cite journal|title=Synthesis of 4,5-Dimethyl-1,3-dithiol-2-one|authors=Perumalreddy Chandrasekaran, James P. Donahue|journal=Org. Synth.|year=2009|volume=86|pages=333|doi=10.15227/orgsyn.086.0333}} They are often derived by hydrolysis of the corresponding trithiocarbonates (RS)2CS. One example is tetrathiapentalenedione, a [[heterocycle]] that consists of two dithiocarbonate groups. ==Trithiocarbonates== Trithiocarbonate is the dianion {{chem|CS|3|2−}}, which has D3h symmetry. Trithiocarbonate is derived from the reaction of sulfide sources with carbon disulfide:{{cite journal | journal=Org. Synth.|author = R. E. Strube | title = Trithiocarbodiglycolic Acid | volume = 39 | pages = 967 | year = 1959 | doi = 10.15227/orgsyn.039.0077}}(a procedure for synthesis of K2CS3 :CS2 + 2 [[Sodium hydrosulfide|NaSH]] → Na2CS3 + H2S ==Perthiocarbonates== Addition of sulfur to trithiocarbonate gives the perthiocarbonate anion {{chem|CS|4|2−}}, which contains one sulfur–sulfur bond.[https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/summary/summary.cgi?cid=3034198 Sodium perthiocarbonate o PubChem]
Perthiocarbonic acid (or tetrathiocarbonic acid, CAS#13074-70-9{{cite web |url=http://www.ebuychem.com/product/13074-70-9.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140607005338/http://www.ebuychem.com/product/13074-70-9.html |archivedate=2014-06-07 |df= }}) has never been synthesized in the pure form but only as a dark brown solution.http://sulphur.atomistry.com/perthiocarbonic_acid.html ==References== [[Category:Carbonates]] [[Category:Oxoanions]] [[Category:Sulfur ions]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} [[File:Treehouse_attachment_bolts_2.jpg|thumb|A Garnier limb (GL)]] [[File:Treehouse_attachment_bolts_1.jpg|thumb|Early GL Prototypes]] [[File:Treehouse_attachment_bolts_3.jpg|thumb|An example of tree growth over time, enveloping an older GL, beam & bracket]] '''Treehouse attachment bolt'''s or '''TAB'''s are specialized bolts engineered for [[tree house|treehouse]] construction.<ref name=the>{{cite web|url=http://www.treehouseengineering.com/ |title=""INTRODUCING THE XL SYSTEM ©- FINALLY, A TRUE TREE HOUSE MOUNTING SYSTEM"" (see the link to a brochure)|accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref><ref name="Van Rheenen" /><ref name=pequot>Globe Pequot, "Knack Treehouses: A Step-by-Step Guide to Designing and Building a Safe and Sound Structure", 2010, {{ISBN|0762763426}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7eP3jOihyjgC&pg=PA66 p. 66]</ref> Various models and trademarks exist, with names such as '''Garnier limbs''' (GLs); tree anchor bolts; artificial limbs; heavy limbs or hyper limbs (HLs); special tree fastener or stud tree fastener (STFs).
They may be either of [[through fastener]] style (for smaller trees) or side mount type for larger ones.<ref name=the/>
==Description== One of the main features of TABs is their strength, requiring fewer tree penetrations for robust fastening of a treehouse and hence less damage to a live tree. A typical TAB consists of a threaded metal bolt and a larger diameter collar. The latter provides an extra bending strength by bearing upon the compression strength of the tree grain.<ref name=the/> Since treehouses are subject to frequent load reversal produced by winds, TABs must be made of [[spring steel]]<ref name=the/> The bolts are able to support from between {{convert|9,000|and|12,000|lbs|kg}},<ref name=Goodnow /> a much greater load than conventional [[Screw#Lag screw|lag bolt]]s.
TABs are commonly used in conjunction with [[pipe bracket]]s, allowing the treehouse structure to move independently with the tree.<ref name=NelsonInterview>{{cite web | url=http://land8.com/profiles/blogs/interview-with-pete-nelson-of-animal-planet-s-treehouse-masters | title=Interview with Pete Nelson of ''Animal Planet's'' "Treehouse Masters"}}</ref><ref name=AnimalPlanetBio>{{cite web | url=http://press.discovery.com/ekits/treehouse-masters/bios.html | title=Pete Nelson – the Treehouse Expert | publisher=''[[Animal Planet]]'' | accessdate=28 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="Van Rheenen">{{cite book | title=Moon Living Abroad in Costa Rica | publisher=Avalon Travel Publishing | author=Van Rheenen, Erin | year=2010 | pages=375 | isbn=9781598808445}}</ref><ref name=AboutTreehouseMasters>{{cite web | url=http://animal.discovery.com/tv-shows/treehouse-masters/about.htm | title=About Treehouse Masters | publisher=''[[Animal Planet]]'' | accessdate=28 December 2013}}</ref><ref name=Kurutz>{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/31/garden/pete-nelson-on-the-new-reality-television-series-treehouse-masters.html?_r=0 | title=Houses for Dreamers (and Kids) | publisher=''[[New York Times]]'' | date=29 May 2013 | accessdate=28 December 2013 | author=Kurutz, Steven | quote=Pete Nelson, an owner of TreeHouse Workshop, outside Seattle, is an expert in his field: the design and building of treehouses}}</ref> TABs are designed so a tree’s added girth can further envelop it.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tdn.com/mobile/article_b64cf932-e5bb-11e2-bcc5-0019bb2963f4.html | title= Bird's eye brew: Treetop tasting room draws visitors | publisher= ''[[Akron Beacon Journal]]'' | date=6 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.outsideonline.com/outdoor-gear/design-and-tech/Elevate-Your-Game-Built-Your-Ultimate-Treehouse.html# | title=How to Build the Ultimate Treehouse | publisher= ''[[Outside Magazine]]'' | date=October 2013}}</ref>
==History== The concept of using a collar or large cylindrical object to increase shear strength in wood construction has been around for several centuries in the forms of split rings and shear plates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treehouseattachmentbolts.com/construction.html |title=History of the TAB |accessdate=2014-02-28}}</ref> Shear plates provide a larger load-carrying capacity in shear than can be otherwise achieved by a bolt alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shearplates.com/ |title=Information regarding shear plates |accessdate=2014-02-28}}</ref> Because this idea utilized less bolts for equal strength, it transferred well into the use of live trees, as they compartmentalize more efficiently with a single, larger cut than several, smaller cuts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetreehouseguide.com/treedamage.htm#compartment |title=Live tree reactions to TABs |accessdate=2014-02-28}}</ref> Michael Garnier became involved in treehouse construction<ref name=Goodnow>{{cite web | url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:SPIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11B3A9A213E20EB0&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0FB3382EE6AD1E46 | title=Northwest Innovators Helped Revolutionize Construction | publisher=''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' | date=23 August 2007 | accessdate=28 December 2013 | author=Goodnow, Cecilia}}</ref><ref name=Kugel>{{cite web | url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:MIJB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0FAA9D222C57A367&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0FB3382EE6AD1E46 | title=Refuge among the boughs | publisher=''Marin Independent Journal'' | date=26 April 2003 | accessdate=28 December 2013 | author=Kugel, Seth}}</ref> beginning in 1990 when he built his first treehouse in [[Josephine County, Oregon|Josephine County]], [[Oregon]]. Two years later, he was ordered by County official to close the treehouse to the public. He began developing what would become the Garnier limb, a high-strength alloy steel engineered bolt that can be screwed into a bore in the trunk of tree. In 1997 Garnier met Arborist Scott D. Baker who shared his knowledge of tree biology and tree structural responses. By 1998, Garnier had developed a commercial bolt product which he called Artificial Limbs. The Garnier limb was primarily developed to satisfy the safety requirements of the Josephine County Building and Safety [[Construction permit|building permit]] process.<ref>{{cite book|last=Miskimon|first=Robert|title=The Complete Guide to Building Your Own Tree House: For Parents and Adults Who Are Kids at Heart|year=2008|publisher=Atlantic Publishing Company|isbn=1-60138-244-8|pages=88–89|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7ynNOj4660UC&lpg=PA90&dq=garnier%20limb&pg=PA89#v=onepage&q=garnier%20limb&f=false|author2=Chmienlnicki, Steven |accessdate=29 July 2011|quote=[Michael Garnier's] battle with Josephine County officials in Oregon began when he built his first tree house, Peacock Perch, in 1990. In May of that year, Garnier sought a building permit from Josephine County Building and Safety to build a tree house, but county officials told him he could not even apply for the license." ...[court battles, national press coverage, testing and development]... "In March 1998, the county accepted Garnier's alternative construction methods and engineering as safe and sound and issued permits for existing tree houses, as well as permits to expand the existing bed-and-breakfast permit.}}</ref><ref name=treehouses.com>{{cite web | url=http://treehouses.com/joomla/index.php/construction/garnier-limb | title=Official Garnier Limb Origin and Histree | publisher=Out'n'About Treesort, LLC | accessdate=28 December 2013 | author=Garnier, Michael}}</ref>
[[Engineer]] Charley Greenwood, with the help of Michael Garnier and [[machinist]] Michael Birmingham, added a {{convert|3|in|mm|adj=on}} collar onto a {{convert|1.25|in|mm|adj=on}} [[hex cap screw]] to maximize the surface area and minimize compression in the contact area between the tree and the screw.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treehousesupplies.com/TAB-vs-GL-specs_a/266.htm |title=Creation of the TAB |accessdate=2013-09-21}}</ref> Garnier was initially the sole producer of these bolts under the names, "Artificial Limbs" and "Garnier Limb".<ref name=treehouses.com/>

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Twisted House Front.jpg | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 300px | title = Twisted House | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = John McNaughton (sculptor) | year = {{Start date|2005}} | type = [[Wood]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], [[United States]] | museum = [[Indianapolis Art Center]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|52|43.63|N|86|8|40.01|W|region:US}} | owner = Indianapolis Art Center }}
'''''Twisted House''''' is a public artwork by [[United States|American]] artist [[John McNaughton (sculptor)|John McNaughton]], located at the [[Indianapolis Art Center]] in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], [[United States]].<ref name="Stender">{{cite book|last=Stender|first=Thomas W.|title=The Penland Book of Woodworking: Master Classes in Woodworking Technique|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7dUkZcqBLFIC&pg=PA26&dq=%22Twisted+House%22+indianapolis&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiG6aSIs4rbAhUO2GMKHQ_oDHoQ6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=%22Twisted%20House%22%20indianapolis&f=false|year=2006|publisher=Sterling Publishing Company, Inc.|isbn=1579907687|page=26}}</ref> ''Twisted House'' was installed as part of the Center's ARTSPARK initiative.<ref name="ARTSPARK">{{cite web | author=Indianapolis Art Center | year=2009 | title=ARTSPARK Sculptures | work=ARTSPARK | publisher=Indianapolis Art Center | url=http://www.indplsartcenter.org/userfiles/File/ARTSPARK_harndout_0209.pdf | accessdate=8 January 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925191145/http://indplsartcenter.org/userfiles/File/ARTSPARK_harndout_0209.pdf | archivedate=25 September 2010 | df= }}</ref>
==Description==
The sculpture is made of [[cedar wood]] and depicts a tall house, bent in such a way that it appears to rest on its foundation and roof.<ref name="Rush">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/354022472/?terms=%22Twisted+House%22|title=Interact With Art|last=Rush|first=Gretchen|date=August 12, 2005|work=The Noblesville Ledger|page=A7|accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> The roof of the house digs into the forest floor and five square, glass windows travel upwards on the house and a distorted door juts to the right, open for viewers to interact with—inside one can step and look out a large window looking out into the forest. The windows each have sills with exterior flower holders and fake wood flowers. The piece sits on natural stone placed in the ground and the dirt of the forest grounds.
==John McNaughton==
John McNaughton has been teaching [[woodworking]], drawing and sculpture for over 35 years at the [[University of Southern Indiana]]. Receiving his Bachelor of Science and Master of Arts at [[Ball State University]] and his Master of Fine Arts at [[Bowling Green State University]], he has been awarded two [[National Endowment for the Arts]] awards. His art furniture and sculptures reside in the collections of the [[Smithsonian Institution]], the [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] and the [[White House]].<ref name="indyartsguide">{{cite web|url=https://www.indyartsguide.org/public-art/twisted-house/|title=Twisted House|work=Indyartsguide|publisher=The Arts Council of Indianapolis|accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref>
==Acquisition==
This piece was placed in conjunction with the Center's ARTSPARK which brings together art and nature.<ref name="ARTSPARK"/>
==Information==
According to the Indianapolis Art Center, McNaughton's goal with the work is to show viewers that sculpture can be interactive and touch heavily into the imagination.<ref name="Tour">{{cite web | author=Indianapolis Art Center | year=2008 | title=Twisted House | work= | publisher=YouTube | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4UWrMsyUMdQ | accessdate= 8 January 2010}}</ref>
Starting in June 2010 IAC hosted a "Community Masterpiece" event designed by artist [[Vandra Pentecost]].<ref name="Kightlinger">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/126260632/?terms=%22Twisted+House%22|title=Talk of Our Town|last=Kightlinger|first=Cathy|date=July 4, 2010|work=The Indianapolis Star|page=I6|accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> The mural consists of seven panels with each one depicting ''Twisted House'' in a different artistic style: [[expressionism]], [[Realism (arts)|realism]], [[surrealism]], [[American scene painting]], [[cubism]], [[pop art]] and [[impressionism]]. The two panels for pop art and surrealism were completed at the [[Broad Ripple Art Fair]] by visitors. In July and August the rest of the panels were completed and the full [[mural]] now resides on the Outreach Lawn Wall of the ARTSPARK.<ref name="Masterpiece">{{cite web | author=Indianapolis Art Center | year=2010 | title=Art Center’s Twisted House Gets a New Spin | work=Blog | publisher=IAC | url=http://indplsartcenterblog.com/2010/06/28/art-centers-twisted-house-gets-a-new-spin/v=4UWrMsyUMdQ | accessdate= 8 January 2010}}</ref>
==Reception==
''[[Doug Kirby|Roadside America]]'' describes ''Twisted House'' as "A work of whimsical lopsided outdoor art, suggesting something that's gone terribly wrong at a fairy tale theme park."<ref name="RAMay">{{cite web|title=Indianapolis, IN - Artspark - Twisted House|url=https://www.roadsideamerica.com/tip/16252|website=Roadside America|accessdate=16 May 2018|language=en}}</ref>
